77472108.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. Page 20 of 27
  2. All costs (sorting, handling, shipping, rework and inspection report costs) associated with addressing a non-
  3. conformance will be the supplier’s responsibility. These costs may include any secondary costs incurred by
  4. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) resulting from a non-conformance, such as the costs associated with tear down, reassembly, re-testing,
  5. and logistics support.
  6. 7.1.1 Treatment of Complaints / Rejections
  7. The supplier is responsible for the quality of parts/products delivered at all times, starting from nomination of
  8. the supplier until end of project/product lifetime, EOP + 15 years (or other defined on SoW (Statement of Work)). Supplier  is also
  9. responsible for delivery of the correct parts / products, to the correct Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) location. The supplier’s
  10. responsibility is not only for his individual part, but also for any concerns / rejections / recalls etc. with Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)
  11. products/ parts which have been produced using supplier’s defect / suspect product/parts and are related to
  12. those defect / suspect product /parts. Whenever a quality concern has occurred, the next three deliveries,
  13. with conformance confirmed, must be identified with an extra green label.
  14. 7.1.2 Treatment of Quality & Logistic Complaints / Rejections
  15. The supplier shall apply the eight disciplines (8D) root cause analysis problem solving methodology and have
  16. evidence of official training on problem solving techniques.
  17. The supplier must provide to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) facilities an 8D report which must be in the English language, and which
  18. upon closure, clearly defines and verifies corrective actions implemented to eliminate the root cause.
  19. This process must be carried by the supplier using the web-based Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for
  20. Components (GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components)) (https://gpdb.yazaki-europe.com/sm_apps/). Supplier  GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) manual is posted in the
  21. portal, ASL (All Supplier  List dBase)-MPF Web Interface 2.6.73 (godbweb.azurefd.net), if necessary, further guidance / advice on the
  22. correct use of this system can be obtained from the SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) and/or SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
  23. 7.1.3 Responsiveness / Pro-Activeness
  24. Suppliers are selected because of their competence, qualification and particular commodity experience in an
  25. automotive environment. This includes that suppliers must be responsive and proactive for the entire life of
  26. the product.
  27. Design and Development phase:
  28. Supplier  is responsible to mention risks, advantages and disadvantages related to possible tools during RFQ (Request for Quotation)
  29. negotations related to their investment proposals.
  30. Suppliers must assist Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) project teams to find the best technical solutions at competitive prices, without
  31. compromising the required level of quality.
  32. Production phase:
  33. Suppliers must be committed to provide the necessary resources to resolve any concerns as top priority.
  34. Post-production phase:
  35. Suppliers must be committed to support and take responsibility for any concerns occurring after production
  36. phase i.e. field claims, warranty concerns.
  37. EA-QM
  38. 40, Rev New, 11/12/2024

Total steps identified: 38

92252059.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. Page 21 of 27
  2. 7.1.4 Immediate Corrective Action
  3. The supplier shall name a ‘Champion’, who is the responsible contact person, for each supplier manufacturing
  4. location. When Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and associated companies receive products from more than one supplier manufacturing
  5. location, the supplier shall name a European coordinator to assist communication.
  6. Production flow interruption: In the event of non-conformities, the supplier must provide corrective actions
  7. necessary to ensure Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) production without interruption. These actions may include sorting, rework,
  8. containment, immediate replacement of defectives, and identification of ‘OK’ parts / materials, and the
  9. presence of the supplier’s personnel in the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) facilities affected, at supplier’s cost. Suppliers must respond
  10. within 24 hours (maximum) when notified of a concern.
  11. Agreed containment action may include visits of specific supplier personnel to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) facilities to review /
  12. analyze the concerns. This is in addition to supplier personnel who may be carrying out sort / rework activities,
  13. as referred to above.
  14. Suppliers shall provide Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) with an initial 8D root cause analysis report using the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal, identifying
  15. containment actions (3D) within 24 hours. The appropriate Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) personnel responsible for handling the
  16. concern must review and approve the proposed supplier actions.
  17. 7.1.5 Permanent Corrective Action
  18. Suppliers must provide Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) with 8D root cause analysis, using appropriate Quality Tools, as 5 Whys or
  19. Ishikawa Diagram, the report must be submitted within 10 working days with an 8D report detailing complete
  20. corrective action.
  21. A corrective action-timing plan (in conjunction with 7.1.4 above), must be submitted to the appropriate SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer)
  22. personnel, who must approve the proposed plan / actions.
  23. 7.1.6 Customer Line Returns, Warranty Returns to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and NTF Process
  24. If supplier responsibility is identified, customer line returns and warranty returns will be managed as quality
  25. incidents and reported in the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal. The same process applies as explained in section 7.1.1. For
  26. warranty/field claims, supplier is still responsible for their components even project is end of life, EOP +15
  27. years (or other period mention on SoW (Statement of Work)).
  28. If no defects or reasons for breakdown are found after performing the damaged part analysis, Supplier  shall
  29. agree to perform an NTF process as per VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) volume Damaged part analysis field and/or OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) applicable
  30. standards. The NTF process serves to find the cause of a problem not identified in a damaged part analysis.
  31. 7.1.7 Repetitive Problems
  32. A repetitive problem indicates that the corrective actions according to 8D report were not effective or not
  33. implemented. Moreover, the effectiveness of the corrective action was not verified, as required by the 8D
  34. process.
  35. In the case of repetitive problems, Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) may request supplier’s senior management to visit the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Plant
  36. to propose and commit to a complete business action plan.
  37. Supplier  shall provide 100% inspection and identification of purchased parts /products until the problem is
  38. eliminated (Controlled Shipping), and if requested by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA), must agree to a process audit at the relevant
  39. supplier facility.
  40. EA-QM
  41. 40, Rev New, 11/12/2024

Total steps identified: 41

2380961.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. Page 22 of 27
  2. 7.1.8 Cost of Non-Quality
  3. In the case of quality and supply concerns caused by suppliers and accepted as justified by the supplier, all
  4. direct and indirect costs incurred at Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) in particular for exceeding delivery dates, labor, materials, additional
  5. freight, lack of output, plus any other associated costs will be fully charged back to the delinquent supplier.
  6. This will be based upon the data collected via the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal (Cost Agreement) related to the length /
  7. magnitude of the concern /rejection.
  8. EA-QM-xx-S-933 Supplier  Non-conformity Cost Agreement, available on GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) Site, ASL (All Supplier  List dBase)-MPF Web Interface
  9. 2.6.73 (godbweb.azurefd.net)
  10. 7.2 Quality Objectives - Quality Improvement Plan
  11. Suppliers are expected to use the lessons learned from each incident to improve production process, product
  12. design, or underlying business systems. The goal is to eliminate the possibility of similar incidents, not only by
  13. making procedural and process adjustments on the manufacturing floor, but by removing the environment
  14. that allowed the issue to surface. Lasting improvement requires correcting the systems and strategies that
  15. support the production process.
  16. In addition to responding to identified non-conformances, suppliers should use statistical data to continually
  17. evaluate and refine their processes. This evaluation should include analysis of quality out of control indications,
  18. high PPM (Parts Per Million), scrap, downtime, and warranty failures. The clear objective of this analysis must be reduction of
  19. variation with the finished product. The supplier shall have on-going, active improvement projects that target
  20. two or three of the largest problem areas and be able to demonstrate a positive trend in reducing incidents
  21. and repeat occurrences.
  22. 7.2.1 Zero Defects Philosophy
  23. All suppliers are expected to drive Zero Defects Philosophy throughout their supply chain, aiming to deliver
  24. defect free material at the required time. The ultimate quality target can only be zero PPM (Parts Per Million).
  25. For suppliers defined as high impact, individual PPM (Parts Per Million) Targets per project will be defined and specified,
  26. considering the product and technology as well as given customer requirements, in project specific
  27. documentation.
  28. The quality objective on parts/products used on new projects i.e. projects in ramp-up prior to volume
  29. production, will be negotiated between SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) / supplier at the relevant time, but the ultimate target / objective
  30. will still be defect free deliveries (zero PPM (Parts Per Million)).
  31. 7.2.2 Supplier  Performance Evaluation / Supplier  Score Card
  32. Supplier  Quality & Logistic Performance is measured against KPI (Key Performance Indicator)’s defined on Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Regional Supplier 
  33. Scorecard Manual, available on GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) Site, ASL (All Supplier  List dBase)-MPF Web Interface 2.6.73 (godbweb.azurefd.net)
  34. Downgrading criteria: Subcategory fail (D level). The overall status (A, B, C, D level) is the sum of all KPI (Key Performance Indicator) scores
  35. and considering the downgrading:
  36. SCORE
  37. LEVEL
  38. STATUS
  39. 85 < Score < 100
  40. Preferred
  41. 67 < Score < 85
  42. Acceptable
  43. 50 < Score < 67
  44. Probationary
  45. O.< Score <50
  46. Unacceptable
  47. EA-QM
  48. 40, Rev New, 11/12/2024

Total steps identified: 48

FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. Page 23 of 27
  2. For further detailed information, refer to the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Limited Supplier  Score Card Manual stored at the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA)
  3. Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM).
  4. 7.2.3 Supplier  Development / Quality Improvement Plan
  5. The supplier quality performance is monitored and is the base for deploying development activities to improve
  6. Quality, Cost, Delivery and Environmental objectives.
  7. For suppliers defined as high impact and / or with a decreasing quality performance trend are expected to
  8. deliver a comprehensive Supplier  Quality Improvement Plan (SQIP (Supplier  Quality Improvement Plan)) for continuous improvement of their
  9. system, organization, etc., showing how Quality, Cost, Delivery and Environmental objectives are to be
  10. achieved.
  11. Individual Quality Commitments with quality objectives are set-up by the SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) and agreed with the Supplier 
  12. ona yearly basis, at a minimum.
  13. 7.3 Supplier  Audits
  14. Audits at supplier premises may be performed for following reasons:
  15. New supplier
  16. New supplier location
  17. New / additional business
  18. New process
  19. During APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning), before and or after PPAP (Production Part Approval Process)/Product  approval
  20. Poor performance
  21. After a major incident
  22. Other...
  23. The supplier will be notified in advance in due time in comparison to the audit reason by the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Auditor /
  24. SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) about any planned audit activity. The supplier is responsible to be well prepared for the audit including
  25. submission of the self-assessment in advance in order to assure the audit can be conducted in a proper way.
  26. The Audit format applied is the VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) 6.3 standard but can also be any other Customer specific assessment
  27. questionnaire.
  28. Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) reserves the right to charge the supplier for the expenses incurred if an unacceptable audit score level
  29. or preparation is detected during the on-site audit.
  30. The related costs will be clearly communicated through Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Purchasing.
  31. 7.4 Continuous Improvement
  32. Suppliers to Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) are expected to drive continuous improvement activities throughout the whole
  33. organization.
  34. Besides the basic standards of high level housekeeping / 5S, Visual Management, Mistake Proofing tools (Poka-
  35. Yoke) and good problem solving methods, it is also recommended to implement and maintain a Lean
  36. Management philosophy and principles using tools such as Value Stream Mapping, Single Minute Exchange of
  37. Die (SMED), Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE), Kanban, Standardized Work, Total Productive Maintenance
  38. (TPM) etc. The respective SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) will verify the level of implementation during on-site visits / audits.
  39. EA-QM
  40. 40, Rev New, 11/12/2024

Total steps identified: 40

Process Steps:
  1. Page 24 of 27
  2. 7.5 Supplier  Performance Deviation Management - Escalation process
  3. SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) with level of escalation is communicated through a notification letter that initiates and invites
  4. appropriate Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) and supplier representatives with a formal agenda and appropriate meeting place and time
  5. to develop an improvement plan that will then be followed until the corrective actions are implemented and
  6. followed until the action is satisfactory.
  7. SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) De-escalation letter is sent to supplier when deviating performance is corrected.
  8. More detailed information can be found on https://www.yazaki-europe.com/supplier - Supplier  Private area —
  9. Reference Document EA-QM-xx-S-632 Supplier  Performance Deviation Levels.
  10. SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) process is applicable to both Direct & Indirect Material suppliers.
  11. EA
  12. OM

69671834.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. 1 Scope
  3. The requirements defined in this Supplier  Quality Manual apply to all suppliers of safe and marketable
  4. goods and services, in particular production parts and materials to Plants and BU (Business Unit) customer locations
  5. within the YAZAKI  Europe Group.
  6. The YAZAKI  Supplier  Quality Manual is valid for the supply of production materials, software and
  7. Aftermarket products.
  8. It is also valid for services that affect customer requirements such as sub-assembly, sequencing, sorting,
  9. rework, and calibration services.
  10. It applies to all suppliers along the supply chain providing products to YAZAKI . It is also applicable for
  11. customer directed suppliers (directed buy).
  12. YAZAKI  suppliers are expected to extend the requirements of YAZAKI  Supplier  Quality Manual to their
  13. own suppliers.
  14. This Quality Manual also applies to intra-Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) business to YAZAKI .
  15. 2 Purpose
  16. The purpose of the YAZAKI  Europe Group’s Supplier  Quality Manual is to clearly define the quality system
  17. procedures and disciplines to ensure and maintain a successful and professional relationship between
  18. YAZAKI  Purchasing and suppliers.
  19. These expectations are YAZAKI  specific and are based upon and in addition to the latest editions of the
  20. following International and Global Management Standards: ISO09001, IATF16949, 1SO14001, ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 45001,
  21. Core Quality Tools (APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning), PPAP (Production Part Approval Process), FMEA (Failure Mode and Effects Analysis), SPC and MSA), OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)/Customer Specific Requirements as well as
  22. applicable European Union environment legislation, and any applicable local legal requirements.
  23. Requirements listed in this Manual do not constitute a restriction or exception to any stated regulations
  24. or legal requirements.
  25. YAZAKI  Europe Group depends on the quality, cost, delivery and environment provided by our suppliers.
  26. We are committed to developing strong supplier partnerships through mutual trust and commitment.
  27. 3 Management Systems requirements
  28. 3.1 Quality / Environmental / Health & Safety Management System
  29. YAZAKI  Europe Purchase Policy is wherever possible to only purchase goods & services from suppliers
  30. that hold third party certification for their Quality, Environmental and Occupational Health & Safety
  31. Management Systems. Ultimately, all suppliers will be required to hold third-party certification to latest
  32. editions of |ATF 16949, ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 14001 and ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 45001.
  33. In the case of a certificate suspension decision from the supplier’s IATF recognized Certification body,
  34. YAZAKI  shall be informed by the supplier within 30 days of the decision. If no recertification is planned,
  35. the supplier shall inform YAZAKI , at least 3 months prior to the expiration date.
  36. All suppliers of YAZAKI  shall be third party registered to ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 9001 (latest edition) by an accredited third-
  37. party certification body. YAZAKI  Europe Group reserves the right, whenever deemed necessary, to carry
  38. out its own assessments on suppliers and / or their subcontractors (by agreement with the supplier).
  39. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022
  40. 6 of 26
  41. YAZAKI  Europe Group
  42. 2022 (C) COPYRIGHT BY YAZAKI  EUROPE LTD. ANY REPRODUCTION OR DISCLOSURE IS (Initial Sample) PROHIBITED WITHOUT PRIOR WRITTEN CONSENT OF YAZAKI 

Total steps identified: 42

19998142.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. “WW YAZAKI 
  2. IATF 16949 certificates are considered as valid only if provided by an IATF recognized certification body.
  3. Non-compliant suppliers shall provide a timing/transition plan to move as soon as possible to an
  4. approved IATF Certification Body - official list at the IATF site.
  5. 3.1.1
  6. Certificate Management — YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM)
  7. Suppliers are required to manage their certificates of all active sites (Manufacturing locations, Sales
  8. offices & Logistic/ Warehouses/ Distribution Centres) in the YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM). Latest versions of
  9. Management System certificates shall be uploaded in this portal, as a minimum ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 9001, IATF 16949,
  10. ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 14001 and ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 45001 certificates, other certificates are optional. Automatic system messaging to
  11. supplier users is activated once certificate expiry dates are entered. For further details refer to the °
  12. YAZAKI  Europe Group Certificate Manual’ posted at the Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM)
  13. 3.2 Regulatory and Statutory Compliance
  14. The supplier shall apply the legal requirements of the production location and of the country of use (if
  15. named by YAZAKI ) during the APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning) phase to all products, processes or services (internal and external).
  16. This process shall be completed at the latest by PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission.
  17. YAZAKI  suppliers shall adhere to and pass down all applicable statutory and regulatory requirements to
  18. their suppliers in the entire supply chain.
  19. 3.3. Environmental Protection
  20. The supplier shall take responsibility to ensure compliance to all relevant environmental legislation, both
  21. applicable to the regions where goods are produced and/or sold or services are performed, as well as
  22. any additional specific requirements from customers. When necessary, investigations within the supply
  23. chain shall be done to assure all requirements are communicated effectively and complied with.
  24. Effective environmental management, which ensures compliance with the respective applicable
  25. environmental regulations and improves continuously and efficiently the environmental conditions of
  26. the supplier, is an essential contribution towards supply security.
  27. YAZAKI  is committed to the protection of the environment. All YAZAKI  plants are ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 14001 certified.
  28. We therefore expect our suppliers to show voluntary commitment to environmental protection by
  29. implementing an environmental management system.
  30. Upon request, suppliers shall provide recycling and disposal concepts appropriate for their products and
  31. related quantities. Additional data such as water consumption and wastewater, energy consumption
  32. and emissions (CO2, VOC) may be requested for life cycle assessment of YAZAKI  products.
  33. All products and materials (including packaging thereof) delivered to YAZAKI  shall be conform with
  34. below regulatory requirements:
  35. e
  36. ELV (End of Life Vehicle), Directive 2000/53/EC
  37. e
  38. REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals), Regulation (EC) No. 1907/2006
  39. e
  40. ROHS (Restriction of Hazardous Substances), Directive 2011/65/EU
  41. CLP (Classification, Labeling and Packaging), Regulation (EC) No. 1272/2008
  42. Biocidal Products, Regulation (EU) No. 528/2012
  43. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022

  5. Waste Framework, Directive 2008/98/EC

  7. Turkey CLP (Classification, Labeling and Packaging) — SEA Regulation, Official gazette No. 28848

  13. plus all applicable revisions and amendments to the legislation that affect products in the supply chain
  14. and other local applicable legislations.
  15. IMDS (International Material Data System) - International Material Data System, see http://www.mdsystem.com
  16. In order to collect the necessary material data information, YAZAKI  requires that suppliers report it
  17. through the International Material Data System directly.
  18. YAZAKI ’s IMDS (International Material Data System) Company ID# is 223417. YAZAKI ’s acceptance criteria are based on IMDS (International Material Data System)

  21. comply with the recommendations of the IMDS (International Material Data System) system.

  25. Chemicals. This includes communication obligations of SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern) in articles, even for spare parts and
  26. packaging.

  28. products defined as ‘substances’ or ‘mixtures into the area of validity of the REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) regulation. The OR
  29. ensures that the REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) obligations are met. The OR’s name has to be notified to the YAZAKI .
  30. REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern)
  31. All substances added to the Candidate List and present in products above 0.1% w/w must be notified to
  32. YAZAKI . When the Candidate List is updated and new Substances of Very High Concern (SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern)) are added
  33. then the obligation for suppliers to inform their customers becomes immediately effective.
  34. The supplier is requested not to use SVHC (Substances of Very High Concern) in articles and mixtures delivered to YAZAKI .
  35. REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) Annex XIV (Authorization List)
  36. Supplier  shall not use any substance included in this list.
  37. REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) Annex XVII (Restriction List)
  38. Supplier  shall only use substances from the list if it complies with the restrictions.

  40. For chemical products and raw materials suppliers are required to send an updated SDS (Safety Data Sheet) to YAZAK|I in
  41. English language and in the local language of the YAZAKI  affiliates using these products. The SDS (Safety Data Sheet) must
  42. be in accordance with REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) and CLP (Classification, Labeling and Packaging) legislation requirements.

79975031.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. 3.4 Corporate Social Responsibility and Supplier 's Code of Conduct
  3. YAZAKI  follows Corporate Social Responsibility activities based on the global YAZAKI  Group Corporate
  4. Social Responsibility Policy and Strategy. YAZAKI  specifies detailed requirements towards its suppliers in
  5. the document ‘Supplier ’s Code of Conduct’. The whole set of documents is available on YAZAKI ’s
  6. homepage, section ‘Suppliers - Purchasing Documents’.
  7. 3.5 Product  Safety
  8. Product  safety and product liability are particularly significant for companies in the automotive industry.
  9. The supplier has producer responsibility (product liability) for their parts and processes, including parts
  10. or processes from sub-suppliers, which YAZAKI  purchases to build their final products. Therefore, in
  11. order to prevent product liability risks, it is the responsibility of the supplier to do everything in their
  12. power, in terms of organization and technical matters, to guarantee the product safety.
  13. The supplier shall have a documented process for the management of “product safety” related products
  14. and manufacturing processes.
  15. YAZAKI  Europe Group requires their suppliers to designate a Product  Safety Representative (PSR) to be
  16. in charge of all related tasks described in IATF 16949 section 4.4.1.2.
  17. Furthermore, the supplier shall apply these requirements to their supply chain.
  18. 3.6 Cybersecurity
  19. Supplier  must be able to demonstrate an Information Security Program which is formal, supported and
  20. maintained. This includes, but is not limited to:
  21. e
  22. Information Security policies and controls
  23. e
  24. Security Incident Response and Communication Plan
  25. e
  26. Security Awareness Program which includes simulations and user training
  27. e
  28. Identification and Management of security risks
  29. Evidence of compliance may include an Information Security Certification (e.g., |S027001, TISAX, SOC (Substances of Concern) 1
  30. or 2) from an external auditing body or a security assessment initiated by Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) which may be
  31. performed onsite or remote.
  32. Supplier  agrees to respond to requests about policies and timely report any cybersecurity breaches that
  33. could impact YAZAKI .
  34. 4 New Parts/Products
  35. For each new part / product or first time buy for YAZAKI , the supplier must submit initial samples (IS (Initial Sample))
  36. with a complete report, handling manuals and other supporting documents in accordance with
  37. requirements of IATF 16949, related AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) / VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) manuals APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning) & PPAP (latest edition) and any other
  38. OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)/Customer specific requirements specified during contract release free of charge. The report must
  39. contain YAZAKI  part number, technical engineering level and clear and complete supplier identification
  40. data. PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) packages must be complete, accurate and up to date for the products / parts in question
  41. always. Samples shall be provided free of charge to PTC (Porto Technical Centre) Testing Centre for SoC (Substances of Concern) testing, to the relevant
  42. YAZAKI  manufacturing plant for assembly trials, and to the SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) upon request (see 4.6).
  43. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022
  44. 9 of 26
  45. YAZAKI  Europe Group
  46. 2022 (C) COPYRIGHT BY YAZAKI  EUROPE LTD. ANY REPRODUCTION OR DISCLOSURE IS (Initial Sample) PROHIBITED WITHOUT PRIOR WRITTEN CONSENT OF YAZAKI 

Total steps identified: 46

For all YAZAKI  designed products / parts and upon request of YAZAKI , APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning) or VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) MLA (Maturity Level Assurance (acc. to VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association))))/RGA

  21. product (in accordance with IATF 16949 and any other OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) / Customer specific requirement. See also
  22. Section 4.2.
  23. 4.2. Customer Specific Requirements
  24. Supplier  is responsible to follow and implement latest revision of Customer Specific Requirement,
  25. available on https://www.iatfglobaloversight.org/oem-requirements/customer-specific-requirements/.
  26. General customer specific requirements included in this Manual shall be implemented.
  27. Additional customer specific requirements issued by YAZAKI  OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) customers will be communicated on
  28. a project basis. Their application will be subject to an agreement between YAZAKI  and the supplier.
  29. 4.3 Reasons for Initial Samples
  30. The PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) Approval Process is required if any of the following changes apply at the supplier or sub-
  31. supplier:
  32. if a product is ordered for the first time
  33. after the supplier has changed a subcontractor
  34. for all affected characteristics after any product modification
  35. for all affected characteristics following a drawing index modification
  36. following an interruption in delivery after a stop shipment (business on hold)
  37. following an interruption in delivery of more than one year
  38. following an interruption in production of more than one year
  39. if production procedures/processes have been changed

  33. 4.7. Capacity Verification (Run at Rate)
  34. A Run at Rate (R@R) is a performance driven trial run under serial production conditions, this can be
  35. one-day production or an agreed deviating time period, by Advance Supplier  Quality Engineer.
  36. The purpose of R@R is to demonstrate that YAZAKI  requirements for supplier capacity are met, to
  37. provide evidence that the supplier can produce the required volumes to specification with existing
  38. capacity and to identify potential process weaknesses.
  39. Potential reasons for performing R@R:
  40. e
  41. new product/ new supplier
  42. e
  43. changes in product, process or equipment
  44. e
  45. capacity increase
  46. e
  47. relocation of tool and/or equipment
  48. e
  49. supplier performance problems
  50. Unless otherwise agreed, the R@R shall be applied to all production material supplied to YAZAKI . The
  51. R@R Tool specified by YAZAKI  shall be used.
  52. Catalogue parts are excluded from this R@R requirement. In case of any exception from performing a
  53. R@R, supplier capacity for the respective parts shall then be assured and documented with a separate
  54. capacity commitment signed by the supplier.
  55. The R@R shall be conducted either on all process steps or on individual bottleneck/critical process steps.
  56. When limited to individual process steps, the reason(s) shall be documented.

10613429.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. R@R result shall be provided using the YAZAKI  R@R Verification Form signed by the Supplier .
  3. The signed form R@R Verification is required for PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) documentation.
  4. 4.8 CQI/Qualification of Special Processes
  5. The AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) is publisher of the CQl/guidelines (Continuous Quality)
  6. Improvement), CQ! formats are available at http://www.aiag.org/.
  7. For suppliers and sub-suppliers dealing with special processes according to AIAG, relevant CQI-guidelines
  8. shall be considered.
  9. If the result shows findings of the type “Néediforlmmediate Action” jor “Fail Findings”, the supplier shall
  10. inform YAZAKI  immediately and provide an action plan.
  11. 4.9 Customer’s Property
  12. All tools for manufacturing, testing or inspection equipment belonging to YAZAKI  or customers of YAZAKI 
  13. shall be permanently marked to clearly show that they are property of YAZAKI  or of the customer of
  14. YAZAKI . These tools shall only be used for YAZAKI  products, unless an authorization in writing exists.
  15. Tools cannot be relocated to other manufacturing location or subcontracted to 3" parties without prior
  16. written approval from YAZAKI .
  17. 4.10 Packaging
  18. Material packaging is part of the PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) and as such to be agreed and validated during project phase,
  19. prior to PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) approval. Packaging material must be according to REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) regulation, Packaging
  20. directive, customer and local requirements. A ‘Packaging Specification’ template is available at the
  21. YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM). For further details see ‘YAZAKI  Supplier  Logistics Manual’
  22. 4.11 Communication of Approval
  23. SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) will notify supplier with a documented approval or rejection of the IS (Initial Sample) and PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission. In the
  24. event of rejection, YAZAKI  Purchasing will be notified for consideration in tool payments. Until Full
  25. Approval, Green PPAP (Production Part Approval Process), complete tool payment to supplier will not be done.
  26. 4.12 Safe Launch
  27. Safe Launch planning is designed to protect both YAZAKI  and the supplier during the initial phases of
  28. product supply. A Safe Launch process shall be implemented to detect symptoms of potential issues in
  29. new processes and to ensure that new launches are defect free. To accomplish this, a Safe Launch Plan
  30. shall be agreed during the planning phase. During Safe Launch, an increased frequency of inspection and
  31. monitoring shall be performed on designated and other agreed characteristics.
  32. The supplier nominates an empowered interdisciplinary team with defined responsibilities to ensure
  33. the conformity of the parts and to analyze and eliminate internal rejects in a timely manner.
  34. In general, the Safe Launch phase starts with the PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission and extends until start of
  35. production (SOP of the YAZAKI  customer) + 90 days, unless otherwise specified by YAZAKI . The program
  36. duration may also be specified by a quantity of product.
  37. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. Zero defect supplies during the entire Safe Launch phase and fulfillment of all agreed criteria qualify the
  3. supplier for an exit out of the Safe Launch phase.
  4. Any defect discovered during the Safe Launch Phase resets the event to “O” and the Safe Launch Phase
  5. is restarted.
  6. Filled in Safe Launch forms, inspection raw data and capability charts shall be submitted on agreed
  7. frequency to YAZAKI  by means of the information exchange platforms defined by YAZAKI .
  8. 5 Electronic components
  9. For suppliers who develop and/or produce, assemble or test electronic components (particularly
  10. semiconductor devices, passive components and LED components) the additional, specific requirements
  11. described in section 5S shall be applied
  12. 5.1 AECQ
  13. Suppliers who develop and/or produce, assemble or test electronic components shall at a minimum
  14. fulfill the respective qualification standard from the Automotive Electronics Council (AEC; e.g. AECQ 100;
  15. AECQ 101; AECQ 200). Exceptions or deviations to above, shall be communicated to and agreed with
  16. YAZAKI .
  17. 5.2
  18. IPC Standards
  19. IPC enables reliable, high-quality electronics by developing the trusted standards that drive the global
  20. electronics industry's success. Implemented industry-wide, our standards simply communicate and
  21. clarify expectations for everyone within the industry. IPC standards help ensure superior quality,
  22. reliability and consistency in electronics manufacturing. (https://ipc.org/).
  23. Consider the requirements of last issued IPC Tree to the comparable mode of component type (ex. PCB
  24. Panel, Full Assembly PCB)
  25. 5.3 Robustness Validation
  26. The supplier shall provide their approach to robustness validation in the development phase. In addition,
  27. the procedure of robustness validation shall be made available to YAZAKI  for review and approval. For
  28. further information, refer to ZVEl - Handbook of Robustness Validation.
  29. 5.4 Mission Profile for Electronic Components
  30. YAZAKI  may issue a series of work documents to be considered by the supplier:
  31. e
  32. Mission Profile
  33. e
  34. Statement of Work (SOW) and/or
  35. e
  36. Manufacturing Process items at customer (PCB Assembly, Displays, etc Technical Manufacturing
  37. Rules and Conditions)
  38. Technical Cleanliness Requirements according VDA19
  39. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022
  40. 15 of 26

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. 5.5 Software and Components with Embedded Software
  3. Suppliers who develop or supply software or electronic components with integrated software shall
  4. demonstrate the capability of their software development process according to Automotive SPICE or an
  5. equivalent standard. Unless otherwise agreed, the software development capability level 3 needs to be
  6. fulfilled according to the VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) Volume “Automotive SPICE Process Assessment Model” for processes
  7. which are part of the “VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) process scope.
  8. YAZAKI  retains the right to carry out an assessment at the supplier’s location.
  9. If the agreed software development process capability level cannot be achieved, the supplier shall
  10. provide an action plan including an adequate time schedule to achieve the agreed software
  11. development process capability leve
  12. |.”
  13. 5.6 Functional Safety
  14. When safety-relevant electronics and/or software (product or services) are included in the scope of
  15. supply, then supplier shall be “state-of-the-art” and comply with ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 26262.
  16. Safety-relevant parts, their documentation and the drawings shall be marked as such so that they can
  17. be clearly identified throughout the development phase and series production process.
  18. On RFQ (Request for Quotation), the SoW (Statement of Work) defines the roles, schedule and ISO (International Organization for Standardization) 26262 requirements applicable.
  19. 5.7. Counterfeit electronic components
  20. Distributors / suppliers of electronic components shall provide evidence of genuine components prior
  21. to supplying YAZAKI . Based on the receiving YAZAKI  manufacturing plant requirements, supplier must
  22. submit minimum evidence, but not limited to, pictures of component packaging, packaging label and
  23. component marking. The affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plant can verify the evidence provided with
  24. the original component manufacturer (OCM (Original Component Manufacturer)) and all related costs (warranty field cost, revalidation, etc.)
  25. will be charged in case any deficiency is detected.
  26. Distributors / suppliers are obliged to demonstrate capable component management to avoid any
  27. infiltration of counterfeit components at any time.
  28. 6 Production Requirements
  29. While the production operations ultimately determine the quality of product, ensuring consistent
  30. quality also depends on the capability of supporting processes. The processes described in this section
  31. do not directly determine or improve product quality, but failure of these processes has the potential to
  32. adversely affect product quality.
  33. 6.1 Modified Parts
  34. For YAZAKI -nominated (design) parts, no modifications will be accepted without YAZAKI ’s written
  35. approval. This applies to all modifications suggested or requested by supplier, YAZAKI  and OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer). For non-
  36. YAZAKI  nominated parts, supplier shall inform YAZAKI  in writing according to the Supplier  Initiated
  37. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022

Process Steps:

  4. The effects of any change, including those changes caused by sub-suppliers, shall be assessed, verified

  6. of risks associated with the change shall be documented and assessed.
  7. Any intended change, deviating from the latest PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) approval, shall be communicated to YAZAKI 
  8. to allow for a timely review and approval by YAZAKI .
  9. A “Change” refers to all situations referenced in AIAG (Automotive Industry Action Group) PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) Manual and/or VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) Volume 2, Trigger matrix
  10. of Part history.

  41. YAZAKI  Europe must also be informed in advance with submission of a SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) in the YAZAKI  Supplier 
  42. Portal when products / parts manufactured by suppliers’ subcontractors and when a modification (see

78860267.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. 6.1.3 Process Steps
  3. A
  4. Submission of SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) form, duly filled out, at least 90 days prior to implementation date on
  5. the YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM) including detailed information explaining the change /
  6. modification. See also specific info at the YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM).
  7. SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) info will be analyzed upon receipt. Depending on the modification type, additional
  8. samples might be required at YAZAKI  Europe Pilot plant for functional testing (see 4.3) and
  9. at PTC (Porto Technical Centre) Testing Centre for SoC (Substances of Concern) tests. Alternatively, to the submission of samples for the SoC (Substances of Concern)
  10. test, supplier shall provide a SoC (Substances of Concern) test report (see 4.6). Please contact the YAZAKI  SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
  11. Provision of a change implementation schedule to affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plants.
  12. Provision of evidence about security stock level to ensure parts delivery during any change
  13. related production down time. In the event of irreversible modifications, the security stock
  14. must be validated together with affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plants prior to
  15. implementation of the modification, and records kept and made available to YAZAKI (if
  16. required).
  17. Identification of new / changed part level. Whenever a change occurred packaging of the
  18. next three consecutive deliveries to YAZAKI  manufacturing plants must be identified with
  19. an orange or otherwise agreed label with information, the SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) ID, SICR (Supplier  Initiated Change Request) description, YPN (Yazaki Part Number)
  20. and SPN (Supplier  Part Number).
  21. 6.2 Annual Product  Verification
  22. Verification testing shall be performed annually to ensure the intended design requirements are
  23. maintained. All applicable documents shall be updated to reflect product performance throughout
  24. production, including updates to the original PPAP (or equivalent) submission and dimensional annual
  25. layout. All appropriate design verification documentation must be made available within 48 hours upon
  26. YAZAKI ’s request.
  27. This Annual Requalification shall be agreed with AQSE for every specific project by mentioning it in the
  28. Control Plan and needs to be linked also with OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) specific requirements.
  29. 6.3 Deviations / Concessions
  30. Deviations / Concessions will only be considered for a specific quantity of parts / products or a specific
  31. time frame and must be documented and signed by a YAZAKI  Design Engineer and YAZAKI  SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer)
  32. 6.3.1 Deviation
  33. A Deviation is a written request from a supplier to knowingly manufacture parts/products which in some
  34. way, do not conform exactly to specification i.e. supplier cannot produce parts according to specification
  35. and requests YAZAKI  for deviation approval.
  36. 6.3.2 Concession
  37. A concession is the written request from a supplier to ask YAZAKI  to accept and use parts already made
  38. / in transit, which do not conform to specification, and which the supplier has only become aware of
  39. after manufacture.

34424636.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. 6.3.3. Handling of Deviations / Concessions
  3. Deviations / concession shall be communicated by using the CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form (Component Deviation Approval
  4. Request). The CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form is available at the YAZAKI  Europe Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM). YAZAKI ’s decision on a
  5. deviation / concession will always be given in writing. Representative samples should be submitted with
  6. the CDAR (Component Deviation Approval Request) form to the responsible SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) who will further coordinate with related Engineering Department
  7. and SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) of the affected YAZAKI  manufacturing plant. If YAZAKI  accepts the deviations / concessions,
  8. each delivery must be identified with a label “Deviation / Concession ‘X’”.
  9. 6.4 Product  Traceability
  10. Products supplied to YAZAKI  shall be traceable up to batch production or up to a maximum of 8 hours
  11. of production, whichever is smaller. Supplier  shall ensure that the traceability plan maintains its integrity
  12. all the way back to each production step and inspection lot across the entire supply chain.
  13. The traceability plan must be agreed with YAZAKI  on the supplier’s initiative and installed in enough time
  14. before PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process) submission. YAZAKI  specific requirements for traceability must be taken into
  15. consideration.
  16. 6.5 First In First Out inventory control
  17. Suppliers are responsible to have inventory control systems that positively identify and control obsolete
  18. material to prevent inadvertent shipment to the YAZAKI . Where feasible, suppliers shall maintain First
  19. In First Out (FIFO) inventory management practice. The system for FIFO control must ensure controls
  20. extend to rework/repair, test activity and off-site (sub-contract) processes.
  21. 6.6 Sub-supplier Management
  22. YAZAKI  suppliers are responsible for the development of their sub-suppliers. They shall have the
  23. necessary process, competence and resources to manage their sub-suppliers (including directed-buy
  24. suppliers and outsourced processes) and monitor their performance. They shall also ensure that the
  25. sub-suppliers comply with all the requirements contained in this Manual.
  26. An intent to change a sub-supplier shall be communicated well in advance to YAZAKI . The change of a
  27. sub-supplier can only be implemented upon prior approval by YAZAKI . See section 6.1.2 — Change
  28. Notification across the Supply Chain. Subsequently, Production Part Approval Process (PPA (Production Process and Product  Approval)/PPAP (Production Part Approval Process)) shall
  29. be performed.
  30. YAZAKI  reserves the right to participate in audits and assessments of sub-suppliers regarding quality
  31. management systems, processes, products etc. jointly with the YAZAKI  supplier, YAZAKI ’s customers or
  32. a third party assigned by YAZAKI . Advance notice will be given. YAZAKI  participation in a sub-supplier
  33. audit does not absolve the YAZAKI  supplier from their responsibility to properly monitor and develop
  34. the sub-supplier

  31. 7 Performance Measurements and Corrective Actions
  32. YAZAKI  recognizes that the performance of the supply base has a direct and immediate impact on
  33. organizational performance. In response to this, YAZAKI  has developed a system for the measurement
  34. and evaluation of supplier performance. The indicators resulting from this process are compiled every
  35. month and are reviewed and evaluated at all levels of the YAZAKI  organization. These measurements
  36. are shared by Category SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer), for HIS (High Impact Supplier ) review.
  37. 7.1 Non-conforming material and Corrective action response
  38. It is in the interest of both YAZAKI  and the supplier, to identify and address non-conforming parts as
  39. quickly as possible. Suppliers shall take all necessary actions to respond to non-conforming product that
  40. reach a YAZAKI  facility (production site, warehouse, etc.). Every effort is taken to investigate and
  41. document non-conformances and to notify the supplier immediately.
  42. All costs (sorting, handling, shipping, rework and inspection report costs) associated with addressing a
  43. non-conformance will be the supplier’s responsibility. These costs may include any secondary costs
  44. incurred by YAZAKI  resulting from a non-conformance, such as the costs associated with tear down,
  45. reassembly, re-testing, and logistics support.
  46. 7.1.1 Treatment of Complaints / Rejections
  47. The supplier is responsible for the quality of parts/products delivered at all times, starting from
  48. nomination of the supplier until end of project/product lifetime, EOP + 15 years (or other defined on
  49. SoW (Statement of Work)). Supplier  is also responsible for delivery of the correct parts / products, to the correct YAZAKI 
  50. Europe location. The supplier’s responsibility is not only for his individual part, but also for any concerns
  51. / rejections / recalls etc. with YAZAKI  products/ parts which have been produced using supplier’s defect
  52. / suspect product/parts and are related to those defect / suspect product /parts. Whenever a quality
  53. concern has occurred, the next three deliveries, with conformance confirmed, must be identified with
  54. an extra green label.
  55. 7.1.2. Treatment of Quality & Logistic Complaints / Rejections
  56. The supplier shall apply the eight disciplines (8D) root cause analysis problem solving methodology and
  57. have evidence of official training on problem solving techniques.

94593335.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. The supplier must provide to YAZAKI  facilities an 8D report which must be in the English language, and
  3. which upon closure, clearly defines and verifies corrective actions implemented to eliminate the root
  4. cause.
  5. This process must be carried by the supplier using the web-based YAZAKI  Global Quality Reporting
  6. System for Components (GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components)) (https://gpdb.yazaki-europe.com/sm_apps/). User Manuals are
  7. posted in the portal, if necessary, further guidance / advice on the correct use of this system can be
  8. obtained from the SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) and/or SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer).
  9. 7.1.3. Responsiveness / Pro-Activeness
  10. Suppliers are selected because of their competence, qualification and particular commodity experience
  11. in an automotive environment. This includes that suppliers must be responsive and proactive for the
  12. entire life of the product.
  13. Design and Development phase:
  14. Supplier  is responsible to mention risks, advantages and disadvantages related to possible tools during
  15. RFQ (Request for Quotation) negotations related to their investment proposals.
  16. Suppliers must assist YAZAKI  project teams to find the best technical solutions at competitive prices,
  17. without compromising the required level of quality.
  18. Production phase:
  19. Suppliers must be committed to provide the necessary resources to resolve any concerns as top priority.
  20. Post-production phase:
  21. Suppliers must be committed to support and take responsibility for any concerns occurring after
  22. production phase i.e. field claims, warranty concerns.
  23. 7.1.4
  24. Immediate Corrective Action
  25. The supplier shall name a ‘Champion’, who is the responsible contact person, for each supplier
  26. manufacturing location. When YAZAKI  and associated companies receive products from more than one
  27. supplier manufacturing location, the supplier shall name a European coordinator to assist
  28. communication.
  29. Production flow interruption: In the event of non-conformities, the supplier must provide corrective
  30. actions necessary to ensure YAZAKI  production without interruption. These actions may include sorting,
  31. rework, containment, immediate replacement of defectives, and identification of ‘OK’ parts / materials,
  32. and the presence of the supplier’s personnel in the YAZAKI  facilities affected, at supplier’s cost. Suppliers
  33. must respond within 24 hours (maximum) when notified of a concern.
  34. Agreed containment action may include visits of specific supplier personnel to YAZAKI  facilities to review
  35. / analyze the concerns. This is in addition to supplier personnel who may be carrying out sort / rework
  36. activities, as referred to above.
  37. Suppliers shall provide YAZAKI  with an initial 8D root cause analysis report using the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal,
  38. identifying containment actions (3D) within 24 hours. The appropriate YAZAKI  SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) personnel
  39. responsible for handling the concern must review and approve the proposed supplier actions.
  40. 21 of 26
  41. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022
  42. YAZAKI  Europe Group

42027432.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. 7.1.5 Permanent Corrective Action
  3. Suppliers must provide YAZAKI  with 8D root cause analysis report within 10 working days with an 8D
  4. report detailing complete corrective action.
  5. A corrective action-timing plan (in conjunction with 7.1.4 above), must be submitted to the appropriate
  6. SQA (Supplier  Quality Assurance Engineer) personnel, who must approve the proposed plan / actions.
  7. 7.1.6 Customer Line Returns and Warranty Returns to YAZAKI 
  8. If supplier responsibility is identified, customer line returns and warranty returns will be managed as
  9. quality incidents and reported in the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal. The same process applies as explained in section
  10. 7.1.1. For warranty/field claims, supplier is still responsible for their components even project is end of
  11. life, EOP +15 years (pr other period mention on SoW (Statement of Work)).
  12. 7.1.7 Repetitive Problems
  13. A repetitive problem indicates that the corrective actions according to 8D report were not effective or
  14. not implemented. Moreover, the effectiveness of the corrective action was not verified, as required by
  15. the 8D process.
  16. In the case of repetitive problems, YAZAKI  may request supplier’s senior management to visit the YAZAKI 
  17. Europe plant to propose and commit to a complete business action plan.
  18. Supplier  shall provide 100% inspection and identification of purchased parts /products until the problem
  19. is eliminated (Controlled Shipping), and if requested by YAZAKI , must agree to a process audit at the
  20. relevant supplier facility.
  21. 7.1.8 Cost of Non-Quality
  22. In the case of quality and supply concerns caused by suppliers and accepted as justified by the supplier,
  23. all direct and indirect costs incurred at YAZAKI  in particular for exceeding delivery dates, labor, materials,
  24. additional freight, lack of output, plus any other associated costs will be fully charged back to the
  25. delinquent supplier. This will be based upon the data collected via the GQRS-C (Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Global Quality Reporting System for Components) portal (Cost Agreement)
  26. related to the length / magnitude of the concern /rejection.
  27. 7.2 Quality Objectives - Quality Improvement Plan
  28. Suppliers are expected to use the lessons learned from each incident to improve production process,
  29. product design, or underlying business systems. The goal is to eliminate the possibility of similar
  30. incidents, not only by making procedural and process adjustments on the manufacturing floor, but by
  31. removing the environment that allowed the issue to surface. Lasting improvement requires correcting
  32. the systems and strategies that support the production process.
  33. In addition to responding to identified non-conformances, suppliers should use statistical data to
  34. continually evaluate and refine their processes. This evaluation should include analysis of quality out of
  35. control indications, high PPM (Parts Per Million), scrap, downtime, and warranty failures. The clear objective of this analysis
  36. must be reduction of variation with the finished product. The supplier shall have on-going, active
  37. improvement projects that target two or three of the largest problem areas and be able to demonstrate
  38. a positive trend in reducing incidents and repeat occurrences.
  39. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022
  40. 22 of 26
  41. YAZAKI  Europe Group

83770541.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. WW YAZAKI 
  2. 7.2.1 Zero Defects Philosophy
  3. All suppliers are expected to drive Zero Defects Philosophy throughout their supply chain, aiming to
  4. deliver defect free material at the required time. The ultimate quality target can only be zero PPM (Parts Per Million).
  5. For suppliers defined as high impact, individual PPM (Parts Per Million) Targets per project will be defined and specified,
  6. considering the product and technology as well as given customer requirements, in project specific
  7. documentation.
  8. The quality objective on parts/products used on new projects i.e. projects in ramp-up prior to volume
  9. production, will be negotiated between SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) / supplier at the relevant time, but the ultimate target /
  10. objective will still be defect free deliveries (zero PPM (Parts Per Million)).
  11. 7.2.2 Supplier  Performance Evaluation / Supplier  Score Card
  12. Supplier  Quality & Logistic Performance is measured against following KPI (Key Performance Indicator)'s:
  13. 1
  14. PPM (Parts Per Million) Performance
  15. 2
  16. Rejection Performance - Rejections per million (RPM)
  17. 3D Reactivity Performance
  18. 8D Reactivity Performance
  19. Documentation Performance
  20. Delivery Performance
  21. Number of Rejections
  22. Line-stop Performance
  23. 3D Reactivity Performance of Customer Concern
  24. Downgrading criteria: Subcategory fail (D level). The overall status (A, B, C, D level) is the sum of all KPI (Key Performance Indicator)
  25. scores and considering the downgrading:
  26. SCORE
  27. LEVEL
  28. | STATUS
  29. 85 < Score < 100
  30. A
  31. | Preferred
  32. 67 < Score < 85
  33. B
  34. | Acceptable
  35. 50 < Score < 67
  36. C
  37. | Probationary
  38. |
  39. 0 < Score < 50
  40. D
  41. | Unacceptable
  42. |
  43. For detailed information, refer to the YAZAKI  Europe Limited Supplier  Score Card Manual stored at the
  44. YAZAKI  Supplier  Portal (EmpowerQLM).
  45. 7.2.3 Supplier  Development / Quality Improvement Plan
  46. The supplier quality performance is monitored and is the base for deploying development activities to
  47. improve Quality, Cost, Delivery and Environmental objectives.
  48. For suppliers defined as high impact and / or with a decreasing quality performance trend are expected
  49. to deliver a comprehensive Supplier  Quality Improvement Plan (SQIP (Supplier  Quality Improvement Plan)) for continuous improvement of
  50. their system, organization, etc., showing how Quality, Cost, Delivery and Environmental objectives are
  51. to be achieved.

13277661.page_content:
FLOWCHART / PROCESS DIAGRAM:

Process Steps:
  1. “WW YAZAKI 
  2. Individual Quality Commitments with quality objectives are set-up by the SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) and agreed with the
  3. Supplier  on a yearly basis, at a minimum.
  4. 7.3 Supplier  Audits
  5. Audits at supplier premises may be performed for following reasons:
  6. e
  7. New supplier
  8. e
  9. New supplier location
  10. New / additional business
  11. New process
  12. During APQP (Advanced Product  Quality Planning), before and or after PPAP (Production Part Approval Process)/Product  approval
  13. Poor performance
  14. e
  15. After a major incident
  16. e
  17. Other...
  18. The supplier will be notified in advance in due time in comparison to the audit reason by the YAZAKI 
  19. Auditor / SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) about any planned audit activity. The supplier is responsible to be well prepared for the
  20. audit including submission of the self-assessment in advance in order to assure the audit can be
  21. conducted in a proper way. The Audit format applied is the VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) 6.3 standard but can also be any other
  22. Customer specific assessment questionnaire.
  23. YAZAKI  reserves the right to charge the supplier for the expenses incurred if an unacceptable audit score
  24. level or preparation is detected during the on-site audit.
  25. The related costs will be clearly communicated through YAZAKI  Purchasing.
  26. 7.4 Continuous Improvement
  27. Suppliers to YAZAKI  are expected to drive continuous improvement activities throughout the whole
  28. organization.
  29. Besides the basic standards of high level housekeeping / 5S, Visual Management, Mistake Proofing tools
  30. (Poka-Yoke) and good problem solving methods, it is also recommended to implement and maintain a
  31. Lean Management philosophy and principles using tools such as Value Stream Mapping, Single Minute
  32. Exchange of Die (SMED), Overall Equipment Effectiveness (OEE), Kanban, Standardized Work, Total
  33. Productive Maintenance (TPM) etc. The respective SQE (Supplier  Quality Engineer) will verify the level of implementation during
  34. on-site visits / audits.
  35. 7.5 Supplier  Performance Deviation Management - Escalation process
  36. SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) with level of escalation is communicated through a notification letter that initiates and invites
  37. appropriate YAZAKI  and supplier representatives with a formal agenda and appropriate meeting place
  38. and time to develop an improvement plan that will then be followed until the corrective actions are
  39. implemented and followed until the action is satisfactory.
  40. SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) De-escalation letter is sent to supplier when deviating performance is corrected.
  41. More detailed information can be found on https://www.yazaki-europe.com/supplier - Supplier  Private
  42. area — Reference Document EA-PU-xx-P-632 Supplier  Performance Deviation Management.
  43. SPDM (Supplier  Performance Deviation Management) process is applicable to both Direct & Indirect Material suppliers.
  44. EA-PU-xx-M-740_New, 17/MAR/2022
  45. 24 of 26

35.1 No Party shall disclose any Confidential Information to any * * *

(including by fax and other forms of electronic transmission) or
orally to the respective other Party with regard to the Agreement
and/or the Supplies, and includes any information, analyses,

derived from, containing or reflecting such information, but

blogs or other types of publication.
36. Non-Assignment
36.1 Under no circumstances may the SELLER transfer, assign or
delegate, in whole or in part, any of its rights or obligations
under its contractual relationship with the BUYER (including, in
particular, any right of payment), whether directly or indirectly
without the BUYER's prior written consent.
36.2 The BUYER is entitled to assign its rights and obligations in
whole or in part, in particular to its affiliates or to a BUYER
Customer.
37. Governing Law and Jurisdiction
37.1 These Terms and any claims relating to the Supplies provided by
the SELLER will be governed by the laws of the country (and
state/province, if applicable) of the BUYER entity issuing the
respective order ("BUYER Location"), excluding the provisions of
the United Nations Convention on Contracts for the International
Sale of Goods and any conflict of law provisions that would require
application of another choice of law.
37.2 Any action or proceedings by the BUYER against the SELLER may
be brought by the BUYER in any court(s) having jurisdiction over
the SELLER or, at the BUYER's option, in the court(s) having
jurisdiction over BUYER Location, in which event the SELLER
consents to such jurisdiction and service of process in accordance
with applicable procedures.
37.3 Any actions or proceedings by the SELLER against the BUYER may
be brought by the SELLER only in the court(s) having jurisdiction
over the BUYER Location.

73311254.page_content:
Revision Date:
Europe Business Management System
15/MAY/2023
EA-SC (Significant/Special Characteristic)-xx-M-001 Revision Level:
Supplier  Logistics Manual
MANUAL REV 1.1
CONFIDENTIAL: This information is Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) property and must follow applicable global and regional confidentiality rules. Copies are
reference only, see network for latest revision.
Foreword
YAZAKI  has always considered customer satisfaction as one of the top priorities.
Competition in national and international markets has intensified significantly in recent
years. Growing customer expectations in terms of quality and flexibility mean that our
company and the entire supply chain face increasingly demanding challenges.
Traditional logistics operations have transformed into an integrated, customer-focused
management function, that increasingly constitutes a strategic success factor in our
company's competitiveness. YAZAKI  Plants depend on cooperation with reliable, expert,
and customer-focused suppliers.
To achieve this challenging objective, the quality of our products and services must be part
of the main considerations when designing new technical solutions.
Delivering high quality product cannot be achieved without packaging providing proper
protection.
Packaging material is a critical part of the YAZAKI  product and service package offered to
our customers.
Our Suppliers are considered as key partners to succeed in achieving the challenging
customer’s objectives.
In this direction, the needs for packaging standard requirements have been growing at the
same time as YAZAKI  Europe Limited’s growing success.
This document is the result of a long study on how to further optimize product packaging with
as purpose to bring values to our business partners: Customers and Suppliers.
This packaging requirements manual is one of the key stones of future YAZAKI  and its
business partner’s success.
We rely on the support of every party in the application of these requirements.
Template: EA-QM-xx-P-001-F-01 Rev1.0 27/APR/2017 Print Date: 15/MAY/2023 Page 1 of 24

9423262.page_content:
Revision Date:
Europe Business Management System
15/MAY/2023
EA-SC (Significant/Special Characteristic)-xx-M-001 Revision Level:
Supplier  Logistics Manual
MANUAL REV 1.1
CONFIDENTIAL: This information is Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) property and must follow applicable global and regional confidentiality rules. Copies are
reference only, see network for latest revision.
1. PURPOSE:
The purpose of this specification is to outline the minimum requirements for packaging
&transportation systems.
This specification has the following objectives:
▪ To protect the components against damage in transit, handling and storage until the
point of use;
▪ Reduce Quality issues and related Logistic costs;
▪ Avoid relabeling
▪ Optimized cube utilization for the handling unit, the loading unit as well as the transport
medium.
▪ To respect ergonomic and safety constraints
Suppliers must use packaging that withstands the various dynamics of all transportation
methods as land, air and sea transport.
2. SCOPE:
This Supplier  guideline applies to all Suppliers and YAZAKI  manufacturing plants shipping
components and raw material to one of the YAZAKI  EUROPE Limited manufacturing plants
and distribution centers in the EMEA (Europe Middle East Africa) region.
All YAZAKI  EUROPE limited manufacturing plants and distribution centers are entitled to
apply these regulations stated in Supplier  Logistics Manual.
For deliveries of YAZAKI  ComBU (Components Business Unit) designed components please consider the additional
Component Packaging Specification [EA-QM-CO-S-027].
Template: EA-QM-xx-P-001-F-01 Rev1.0 27/APR/2017 Print Date: 15/MAY/2023 Page 4 of 24

4. PROCESS DETAILS:
4.1 Reponsibilities
4.1.1 YAZAKI  Responsibilities
▪ Assist the Supplier  with its packaging proposal
▪ Approve the Suppliers packaging proposal
▪ Organize or support supplier during transport operations in regards to agreed
incoterms.
▪ Use the Transport Order Tool to book the adequate transportation mode.
▪ Check documentations ( Manifest , Invoices , POA (Proof of Authorization) , Delivery notes , Customs
documentations.. ) right after the departure of the truck and before reaching
Customs point check.
▪ Define / refine the theoretical receiving window and share it with WH (Wire Harness) Team.
▪ Track deliveries from supplier according to agreed ETA (Estimated Time of Arrival) and if needed activate
contingency plan.
▪ Validate invoices and payment on time to suppliers
4.1.2 Supplier  Reponsibilities
▪ Comply with the YAZAKI  packaging specification and customer (OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer)) specific
requirements
▪ Design & test the packaging (internal dunnage, dimensions, loading unit) based on
these requirements
▪ Submit all required packaging documentation in GPDB (Global Price Database) Capacity Confirmation and
written form (packaging data sheet)
▪ Ensure availability of sufficient quantity of packaging as well as a contingency plan in
order to ensure a continuous supply.
▪ Review packaging for compliance and resubmit for approval in case of quality issues,
part changes that affect the packaging or changes in the packaging specification.
▪ Comply with environmental legal requirements: Packaging directive 94/62/EC,
REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorization and Restriction of Chemicals) regulation (EC) Nº 1907/2006 and also with local requirements.
▪ Supplier  is responsible for the quality of their products and obedience of
requirements stated in the Yazaki (Yazaki EMEA) Supplier  Logistics Manual.
▪ Organize or support YAZAKI  during transport operations in regards to the agreed
incoterms.
▪ Inform X-dock (Cross Dock) carrier for the needed information of deliveries to YAZAKI  entities.
▪ Follow the Transport Order Tool for direct deliveries to prepare deliveries according
to mentioned details by YAZAKI  entity.
▪ Provide documentations ( Manifest , Invoices , POA (Proof of Authorization) , Delivery notes , Customs
documentations.. ) right after the departure of the truck and before reaching
Customs point check.
▪ Comply with all applicable Environment, Health and Safety legal requirements
related directly and / or indirectly to their activity / service provided to YAZAKI . The
Template: EA-QM-xx-P-001-F-01 Rev1.0 27/APR/2017 Print Date: 15/MAY/2023 Page 6 of 24

same applies in relation to YAZAKI  internal specific EHS (Environmental Health and Safety) protocols that may apply to
the type of service to be provided.
▪ Maintain an Internal EHS (Environmental Health and Safety) Management system and commit with adopting EHS (Environmental Health and Safety) best
practices in order to promote Health and Safety and the mitigation of Environmental
Impacts, including but not limited to:
➢ CO2 emissions reduction footprint
➢ Promotion of Waste Recycling and Circular economy
➢ Promotion of Air emissions reduction
➢ Elimination of Safety hazards and work accidents
▪ Cooperate with potential future Environment, Health & Safety surveys to evaluate the
Supplier ’s performance and identify potential opportunities for continuous
improvement on these areas.
▪ Ensure the products are safely loaded and the packages secured for transport,
according to packing rules.
▪ Ensure that one pallet contains goods for only one plant.
4.2 Packaging/Standard Packaging Size
Standard packaging size is packing per item number according to an agreed and fixed
quantity.
4.2.1 Handling Unit Requirements
Handling unit is the packaging / container in which the individual products (e.g. bags of
connectors, reels of terminals, grommets, etc.) are packed per item number.
It is not allowed to mix different part numbers in a handling unit. Different modification
/different revision levels of products also may not be combined in a handling unit.
Packages must be easily handled during opening and closing and for repacking operations.
All handling units must enable stacking, be rigid with no excessive flexing, bowing, buckling
or distortion. They must provide adequate protection to ensure that goods reach end user in
perfect condition. Depending on the shipping conditions and components material e.g. for
sea-freight conditions, environmental effects could require additional packaging material as
desiccant bags, VCI (Volatile Corrosion Inhibitor) paper and corrosion protection.
Quality & packaging systems for all component families listed below as well as any other
components that may not be listed:

Clips / Fasteners Terminal reels
Nuts / Bolts / Screws Convolute Tubing
Connectors Extended Length Plastic Shields/Troughs
Standard parts are hereby defined as parts which are small and / or uniform in configuration
which will fit into a pre-determined set of hand-held / human movable boxes.
Non-Standard parts are hereby defined as parts which require their own packaging system
and / or SLC (Small Load Carrier) and pallet dimensions due to part configurations/sizes in order to ensure
package and part integrity.
The minimum requirements within these guidelines shall be met by all Component Suppliers
shipping Standard & Non-Standard parts to YAZAKI .
These requirements will help YAZAKI  and its Suppliers to achieve a high level of Quality
performance in regard to automotive standards, environmental legal and local requirements
and OEM (Original Equipment Manufacturer) specific needs.
Therefore, it is ultimately the Suppliers responsibility to ensure that their parts arrive at the
end user undamaged.
Suppliers must use packaging that withstands the various dynamics of all transportation
methods as land, air and sea transport.
Only one-part number is permitted to be shipped inside each box. Multiple part numbers
inside one box is not permitted.
4.2.2 Packaging Design & Dimensions
In order to enable a maximum fill rate of the pallet and the pallet footprint the container shall
be modular. The preferred container dimension for the 1.200mm x 800mm footprint can be
found in the following attachment: EA-SC (Significant/Special Characteristic)-xx-M-001-A-01.
The corrugated material must have minimum 44 ECT (Edge Crush Test) to provide a sufficient strength in order
to maintain part quality.
Minimum BCT (Box Compression Test) requirement is explained in section 4.2.9.
The flute direction shall be vertical to optimize the compression strength.
All carton boxes shall be adequately sealed with packaging tape. Staples as well as asphalt
sealing tapes are not allowed. Hand holes should not be used, unless specified by YAZAKI .

4.2.3 Ergonomic Requirements & Container Utilization
The weight per manually handled handling unit is limited to 15kg. In case local legal
requirements imposes a lower weight limit, the legal requirements must be always respected.
Each handling unit shall reach a minimum vertical box density of 90% based on the following
formula:
Height of goods in container
vertical box density (%) =
Height of container
4.2.4 Expendable (One-way, apply to carton/container box) Packaging
Corrugated box material as well as the used internal dunnage shall be 100% recyclable.
During the design of the box and dunnage the loading, unloading, recycling, and disposal
shall be considered.
All the boxes shall be regular slotted container (RSC (Regular Slotted Container (e.g. FEFCO 0201))) with flaps for closure. Half slotted
container (HSC (Half Slotted Container (e.g. FEFCO 0312))) shall not be used.
Figure 1 Authorized carton box types
4.2.5 Returnable Packaging
In case of mutually agreed use of returnable packaging, the ownership as well as the
responsibilities for maintenance, repair, cleaning, tracking, etc. shall be determined during
the sourcing process. Rental of returnable packaging may also be pursued as an option.
For standard parts, the returnable packaging shall conform to the VDA (Verband der Automobilindustrie (German Automotive Association)) or Odette GALIA
packaging standards.
